quest for improved techniques
make the fatal error of inventing
a "super robot" which has a will
and an intellect. These super
robots take advantage of the
armed might of the robots and
begin world revolution. The stirring slogan, "Robots of the world
unite; you have nothing to lose
but men," rings throughout the
world.

Several new steps which the

the past presidency of the IFB.
The puzzle of Sekulow is how

Is not able to shed much light on

he is a candidate for a degree,

BETRAYAL OF A TRUST

dip

After last week 's conference at Homewood House with
representatives of the DSRC, Dean G. Wilson Shaffer announced
that his office would give its unrestrained sanction to the ejection
of any group or individual from the dormitory whose conduct was
contrary to The standards set up by the residence hall's governing
body.
•
Dean Shaffer's statement is the culmination of evenfs'which
have disturbed the usual scholarly attitude of the dorm since the
first of the year. The trouble has arisen primarily from an
unruly element of the freshman class, although a small number
of upperclassmen have also taken part. This freshman clique has
demonstrated an apparent disregard for the dorm's regulatims
and has flaunted the demands of the DSRC.
One disturbing facet of this disregard of authority is that
some of the supposed leaders of the freshman class are included
in this clique.
The policy- of this university has traditionally been one of
mature rules for supposedly mature individuals. Occasionally, as
in this instance, these regulations are infringed 'upon by small
groups of immature underclassmen. An investigation of the
conditions under which students live in the residence halls of
many other universities leaves little doubt the superiority of the
Hopkins system. Yet this freshman clique has repeatedly betrayed
this gift, this trust under which they hope to call themselves
Hopkins men.
Their actions show not only a juvenile conception of the
Hopkins system but a lack of respect and consideration for
the 300 other students in the dorm. We find it hard to brand any
Hopkins student as immatue, but under these'circumstances we
are left with no alternative. This immaturity of behavior must
be corrected for the protection of those who recognize and pride
themselves in the system under which we receive our education. If
constructive criticism fails, drastic action must be taken; that
action, under our system, should, and does come from the student
body. In this case the elected representatives of the dormitory
students have decided to place an ultimatum before the offenders
—conform or get out. This edict now has the backing of the Dean's
office—it is no idle threat.
We feel that not only the best interests of the dorm but of
the university as well would be compromised if this attitude—this
corruption of the traditional laissez-faire system were not corrected. It is a blight, and like all blights should be stamped out
before it has an opportunity to spread.

Graduate Plan
For

MASTER OF SCIENCE
And

DOCTOR OF SCIENCE DEGREES
PURPOSE

To assist outstanding BS graduates in
obtaining their Master of Science and
Doctor of Science Degrees while employed in industry and making a significant contribution to national defense
•
work.
ELIGIBILITY

January and June 1953 graduates receiving BS Degrees in the following fields:
Aeronautical Engineering
Civil Engineering
Electrical Engineering
Electronic Engineering
Mechanical Engineering
Physics
Those chosen to participate in, this Plan
will be from the upper portion of their
graduating class and will have evidenced
unusual, technical ability. They pust
also have evidenced imaginative ability
and possess personality traits enabling

them to work well with others.
CITIZENSHIP

Applicants must be United States citizens who can be cleared for "Secret."
PARTICIPATING UNIVERSITY

Washington University in St. Louis will
participate in this program and candidates for Master of Science and Doctor
of Science Degrees must meet entrance
requirements for advanced students at
this university.
PROGRAM

Under this Graduate Plan the candidate
will work full time at McDonnell Aircraft Corporation until September 1953.
From September 1953, to June 1954
candidates will work at M.A.C. from 28

to 36 hours per week, attending Washington University on an individually arranged schedule. A Master of Science
Degree should be obtained within a
maximum of two calendar years. Under
this arrangement it will be possible for
a candidate to earn approximately 85%
of a normal year's salary and to attend
the university during regular semesters
while working toward his advanced de-

gree.
COMPENSATION

Compensation will be commensurate
with the individual's ability and experience. Compensation growth will be on
the same basis as the full time members
of the engineering staff. In addition, the
candidate will be" eligible for all other
benefits accruing to full time employees.
TUITION

Tuition covering the required number of
units necessary to obtain an advanced
degree will be paid by McDonnell Aircraft Corporation.
SELECTION OF CANDIDATES

Candidates will be selected by officials
of McDonnell Aircraft, Corporation and
Washington University.
DATES FOR APPLYING

January 1953 graduates should make informal applications prior to January 10,
1953. McDonnell Aircraft Corporation
will then forward formal applications
which should be returned by January 20,
1953, accompanied by up to date grade
transcripts. Selections will be made during the month of February. June 1953
graduates should make informal application no later than March 15, 1953.

Wrestlers' Fate On Block
As Virginia Squad Invades
For Gym Match Tonight
Tonight in the Homewood gym
the Hopkins grapplers will take
the mat against Virginia in their
opening match of the year, despite a very poor turnout for the
team and a resulting suggestion
from Marshall Turner, Director of
Athletics, that the team be dissolved for this year and the schedule cancelled.
This marks the nadir of the
Hopkins wrestling team which
was only a few years ago one of
the leading small college teams in
tile country. Between 1942 and
1950 the Jays lost the MasonDixon title only once, but last
year they were unable to win a
match in seven tries.
Poor Turnout
This year the turnout for the
squad was one of the, poorest in
the history of the team and at
present there are but eleven active
men on the roster.
Since there are eight weight
classes, it leaves the team in very
poor shape to practice. In fact at
the present moment Coach Carl
Rees is not even sure if he will
have a man in the 137 pound class.
This turnout, combined with the

fact that practice sessions have
had an average attendance of
about three members, prompted
Turner to call a meeting of the
team with the purpose of disbanding it unless more interest
was shown.
After a two hour discussion,
however, it was decided to let the
fate of the team ride on the outcome of the Virginia meet. If this
meet shows that there is a definite
interest in wrestling, the sport
will be continued.
The team appears to have a
good nucleus at present. Adam
Adam Szczypinski and Gordon
Stick, both lettermen last year,
are back again this season. Stick
compiled a three won, four lost
record while Szczypinski copped
one victory NiThile dropping three.
In addition to these two, John
O'Connor and John Wrote11 are
back from last year's team. Rees
also has high hopes for four men
up from the freshman team; Doc
Berlett, Don Courts. Jay Conner
and Charlie Kaufman.
Last year the Cavaliers wallop
ed Hopkins 28-5, with the Jays
winning only one match.

The varsity fencing team is
heading into this year's season
with a nucleus of seven returning
lettermen, according to coach
John Pope.
Undefeated last year, the team
hopes to do as well this year, opening with a bout against the Naval
Academy on January 17, probably
the toughtest of the year.
Assisting coach Pope is cal
Schlick, last year's team captain.
"This team looks good," says
Schlick, "but it will take a lot of
work to beat Navy."
Epeemen Bob Erlandson and
Lou Pederson are team captains,
backed by Bud Howard, Dom
Edelen, and Barry Goldstein in
foil, and Gus Rodriguez in sabre.
Nearly all of last year's freshmen are back giving the team a
strong competitive spirit. "Only
the best men will go to matches
this year," says Pope. "This means
careful elimination bouts before
each meet."
Ever since its inception several
years ago, the fencing team has
steadily grown in numbers and
effectiveness.

Sekti;ow Cites Hopkins Moderation
"Urbane, cosmopolitan, and
affable" are the words which
friends use to characterize Gene
Sekulow, a campus wheel whose
spokes include the chairmanship
of the Honor Commission and
presidency of ODK, as well as
the past presidency of the IFB.
The puzzle of Sekulow is how
he manages to juggle all his activities and high grade academic
work. The prestidigitator himself
Is not able to shed much light on
the problem. Under the New Plan,

he is a candidate for a degree,
which he hopes will be an M.A. in
political science, and which he
hopes to get this coming June,
at the end of four years at JHU.
In his years at Hopkins, Gene
has been one of those for whom
the New Plan face lifting has been
of much significance, and he &inks
the type of student life of which
he has been a part will have to
change also.
However, while a patronizer.of

BETRAYAL OF A TRUST

dip

After last week 's conference at Homewood House with
representatives of the DSRC, Dean G. Wilson Shaffer announced
that his office would give its unrestrained sanction to the ejection
of any group or individual from the dormitory whose conduct was
contrary to The standards set up by the residence hall's governing
body.
•
Dean Shaffer's statement is the culmination of evenfs'which
have disturbed the usual scholarly attitude of the dorm since the
first of the year. The trouble has arisen primarily from an
unruly element of the freshman class, although a small number
of upperclassmen have also taken part. This freshman clique has
demonstrated an apparent disregard for the dorm's regulatims
and has flaunted the demands of the DSRC.
One disturbing facet of this disregard of authority is that
some of the supposed leaders of the freshman class are included
in this clique.
The policy- of this university has traditionally been one of
mature rules for supposedly mature individuals. Occasionally, as
in this instance, these regulations are infringed 'upon by small
groups of immature underclassmen. An investigation of the
conditions under which students live in the residence halls of
many other universities leaves little doubt the superiority of the
Hopkins system. Yet this freshman clique has repeatedly betrayed
this gift, this trust under which they hope to call themselves
Hopkins men.
Their actions show not only a juvenile conception of the
Hopkins system but a lack of respect and consideration for
the 300 other students in the dorm. We find it hard to brand any
Hopkins student as immatue, but under these'circumstances we
are left with no alternative. This immaturity of behavior must
be corrected for the protection of those who recognize and pride
themselves in the system under which we receive our education. If
constructive criticism fails, drastic action must be taken; that
action, under our system, should, and does come from the student
body. In this case the elected representatives of the dormitory
students have decided to place an ultimatum before the offenders
—conform or get out. This edict now has the backing of the Dean's
office—it is no idle threat.
We feel that not only the best interests of the dorm but of
the university as well would be compromised if this attitude—this
corruption of the traditional laissez-faire system were not corrected. It is a blight, and like all blights should be stamped out
before it has an opportunity to spread.

•

Graduate Plan
For

MASTER OF SCIENCE
And

DOCTOR OF SCIENCE DEGREES
PURPOSE

To assist outstanding BS graduates in
obtaining their Master of Science and
Doctor of Science Degrees while employed in industry and making a significant contribution to national defense
•
work.
ELIGIBILITY

January and June 1953 graduates receiving BS Degrees in the following fields:
Aeronautical Engineering
Civil Engineering
Electrical Engineering
Electronic Engineering
Mechanical Engineering
Physics
Those chosen to participate in, this Plan
will be from the upper portion of their
graduating class and will have evidenced
unusual, technical ability. They pust
also have evidenced imaginative ability
and possess personality traits enabling

them to work well with others.
CITIZENSHIP

Applicants must be United States citizens who can be cleared for "Secret."
PARTICIPATING UNIVERSITY

Washington University in St. Louis will
participate in this program and candidates for Master of Science and Doctor
of Science Degrees must meet entrance
requirements for advanced students at
this university.
PROGRAM

Under this Graduate Plan the candidate
will work full time at McDonnell Aircraft Corporation until September 1953.
From September 1953, to June 1954
candidates will work at M.A.C. from 28

to 36 hours per week, attending Washington University on an individually arranged schedule. A Master of Science
Degree should be obtained within a
maximum of two calendar years. Under
this arrangement it will be possible for
a candidate to earn approximately 85%
of a normal year's salary and to attend
the university during regular semesters
while working toward his advanced de-

gree.
COMPENSATION

Compensation will be commensurate
with the individual's ability and experience. Compensation growth will be on
the same basis as the full time members
of the engineering staff. In addition, the
candidate will be" eligible for all other
benefits accruing to full time employees.
TUITION

Tuition covering the required number of
units necessary to obtain an advanced
degree will be paid by McDonnell Aircraft Corporation.
SELECTION OF CANDIDATES

Candidates will be selected by officials
of McDonnell Aircraft, Corporation and
Washington University.
DATES FOR APPLYING

January 1953 graduates should make informal applications prior to January 10,
1953. McDonnell Aircraft Corporation
will then forward formal applications
which should be returned by January 20,
1953, accompanied by up to date grade
transcripts. Selections will be made during the month of February. June 1953
graduates should make informal application no later than March 15, 1953.

Wrestlers' Fate On Block
As Virginia Squad Invades
For Gym Match Tonight
Tonight in the Homewood gym
the Hopkins grapplers will take
the mat against Virginia in their
opening match of the year, despite a very poor turnout for the
team and a resulting suggestion
from Marshall Turner, Director of
Athletics, that the team be dissolved for this year and the schedule cancelled.
This marks the nadir of the
Hopkins wrestling team which
was only a few years ago one of
the leading small college teams in
tile country. Between 1942 and
1950 the Jays lost the MasonDixon title only once, but last
year they were unable to win a
match in seven tries.
Poor Turnout
This year the turnout for the
squad was one of the, poorest in
the history of the team and at
present there are but eleven active
men on the roster.
Since there are eight weight
classes, it leaves the team in very
poor shape to practice. In fact at
the present moment Coach Carl
Rees is not even sure if he will
have a man in the 137 pound class.
This turnout, combined with the

fact that practice sessions have
had an average attendance of
about three members, prompted
Turner to call a meeting of the
team with the purpose of disbanding it unless more interest
was shown.
After a two hour discussion,
however, it was decided to let the
fate of the team ride on the outcome of the Virginia meet. If this
meet shows that there is a definite
interest in wrestling, the sport
will be continued.
The team appears to have a
good nucleus at present. Adam
Adam Szczypinski and Gordon
Stick, both lettermen last year,
are back again this season. Stick
compiled a three won, four lost
record while Szczypinski copped
one victory NiThile dropping three.
In addition to these two, John
O'Connor and John Wrote11 are
back from last year's team. Rees
also has high hopes for four men
up from the freshman team; Doc
Berlett, Don Courts. Jay Conner
and Charlie Kaufman.
Last year the Cavaliers wallop
ed Hopkins 28-5, with the Jays
winning only one match.

the talk reaching up to the clouds. And once in a while-in a classroom, around a study table, or even in a bull session-a really big
idea is born.
Big ideas come, too, from the men and women in laboratories,
business offices, shops. But often these professionals are exploring
a path first glimpsed in college.
How do we know? Because of the many college people who
have come into the Bell System, where big ideas and a lot of dreams
have taken their place in progress. The human voice, carried along
a wire, first across a town, then a state, a nation, and now the world.
Music and pictures and things happening delivered into cities and
hamlets all across the land by radio and television networks.

ideas-whether they're about people, or machines, or ways of doing

heading into this year's season
with a nucleus of seven returning
lettermen, according to coach
John Pope.
Undefeated last year, the team
hopes to do as well this year, opening with a bout against the Naval
Academy on January 17, probably
the toughtest of the year.
Assisting coach Pope is cal
Schlick, last year's team captain.
"This team looks good," says
Schlick, "but it will take a lot of
work to beat Navy."
Epeemen Bob Erlandson and
Lou Pederson are team captains,
backed by Bud Howard, Dom
Edelen, and Barry Goldstein in
foil, and Gus Rodriguez in sabre.
Nearly all of last year's freshmen are back giving the team a
strong competitive spirit. "Only
the best men will go to matches
this year," says Pope. "This means
careful elimination bouts before
each meet."
Ever since its inception several
years ago, the fencing team has
steadily grown in numbers and
effectiveness.

Among the most interesting fields for
engineers at Du Pont is the design of
plants and equipment.
It takes ingenuity of a high order
to translate a small-scale laboratory
operation into all-out commerical
production. Design engineers cannot
always use purchasable equipment
to scale up research findings, even
with considerable adaption. About
half of the time at Du Pont,entirely
new equipment must be designed because of the novelty of the process
developed by research.
For example, a number of unusual
problems were involved in designing
the equipment and plantfor a process
in which hexamethylenediamine,one
of the intermediates for nylon, is
made from furfural, derived from
such agricultural by-products as
corncobs and hulls of cottonseed,
oats and rice.
